item.description:
Currently listening to … Ozarker from Israel Nash üé∂

Listen on Spotify

Currently listening to … In Time by The Emerald Dawn üé∂

I’ve followed this band since seeing them perform at a gig in a friend’s garden last year.

Listen to the single on Spotify or catch the whole album on Bandcamp.

Currently listening to … Status Quo was the first band I saw many decades ago and I’m still listening and enjoying them after all this time, despite there only being Francis Rossi left of the original “Frantic Four.”

This is the new release of a live concert from 2010, with Rick Parfitt. üé∂

Listen on Spotify

Currently listening to the four singles taken from the new album, Carolyn’s Boy from Darius Rucker planned for 6th October. I looking forward to listing to the rest of the album.

‚ÄúI wanted to name the record Carolyn‚Äôs Boy because Mom never got to see any of my success,‚Äù Rucker offered in the interview. ‚ÄúShe died before any of this happened, so it‚Äôs just another homage to the greatest woman I‚Äôve ever known.‚Äù When asked why he wanted to put this album out now, Rucker shared, ‚ÄúYears ago, I wasn‚Äôt really sure what my place in country music was and I was trying to find it. Now I have found it‚ÄîI know‚Äîand I think it‚Äôs time to give that record.‚Äù üé∂

Currently listening to … Threnody For A Dead Queen from Comedy of Errors.

üé∂

Currently listening to … But Here We Are from Foo Fighters.

I think it’ll need a couple of listens before I make my mind up. Listen on Spotify. üé∂

I enjoyed the first episode of “The Gallows Pole” on the BBC yesterday. It’s the tale of the rise of David Hartley and the Cragg Vale Coiners. Set in the moorland hills of 18th Century Yorkshire, the drama follows the enigmatic David Hartley as he assembles a gang of weavers and land-workers to embark upon a revolutionary criminal enterprise that will capsize the economy and become the biggest fraud in British history.

I haven’t read the book, but I suspect it doesn’t end well for the Coiners…

The soundtrack is available on BBC Sounds and on Spotify.

Currently listening to … Mirror to the Sky from Yes.

Really enjoying this album. Listen on Spotify. üé∂

Currently listening to … The Clockwork Saga from Gandalf’s Fist.

This album is available on Bandcamp as a combined 5 act adventure, encompassing all songs from “The Clockwork Fable” (2016) and “The Clockwork Prologue” (2019) Albums in full narrative order. Links open in Spotify.

Currently listening to … First Two Pages of Frankenstein by The National.

This is the first proper album from The National since 2017’s Sleep Well Beast. It’s worth a close listen. Listen on Spotify üé∂

Currently listening to … Fuse by Everything But The Girl.

This is the first album from EBTG in 24 years - it was worth the wait! Listen on Spotify üé∂

Currently listening to … Multitudes from Feist.

Listen on Spotify üé∂

item.title: Roon‚ÄîNot Only For Audiophiles Part 1
item.description:
Why invest in Roon when Apple‚Äôs Music (the app, not the service) and Spotify are ‚Äúfree?‚Äù

I wanted to use Apple Music to bring all my music into one place, consisting of over 2,000 albums I’ve ripped or purchased that sat on a Synology NAS and music from Apple‚Äôs streaming service. Unfortunately, this approach didn’t work because Apple struggled to match my albums with the versions on its servers.

After days spent watching Apple Music processing & uploading, I gave up. The workaround was to have two Apple Music libraries, one for digital files and another for streaming music, which wasn’t an elegant or practical solution.

I own a Naim Uniti Atom, which supports Apple‚Äôs service via AirPlay, but Spotify, Tidal and Qobuz are better integrated. I‚Äôve used Spotify for many years and still have a free account, but the continued lack of high-res content left me looking for another provider. I tried Tidal but grew tired of the way they push music I don‚Äôt like at me. Ultimately, I settled on Qobuz, and bought a 12-month subscription.

I still didn‚Äôt have all of my music in one place. After some research during the Christmas break, I signed up for a 14-day trial of Roon.

As a test, I installed Roon on my MacBook Air, pointed it at a subset of my music collection, added my Qobuz subscription, sat back whilst Roon scanned my music and installed the mobile app on my iPhone and iPad.

Roon must always be on and connected to the Internet to work correctly, so using my MacBook as the Roon server wasn‚Äôt a long-term solution. I couldn‚Äôt use my Synology NAS as it was in storage between houses, and the spec was too low to support Roon.

As an interim solution, I bought a “previously enjoyed” NUC from eBay. I installed Roon ROCK, which is a dedicated operating system and Roon core with the music files located on an external SSD drive. It’s a relatively old i5 model but came with 16Gb RAM. It sits in the kitchen, next to the router and has never missed a beat.

It manages almost 30,000 tracks across my music and what I’ve saved as favourites in Qobuz.

Use this link for a free 30-day trial, but be warned‚Äîit‚Äôs addictive.

In Part 2, I’ll talk about some of the benefits of using Roon.

Listening to … Dub No Frontiers by Adrian Sherwood

This was recommended by i newspaper’s Ian Dunt, who said:

Really well thought-through collection by British producer Adrian Sherwood, who challenges the male-dominated world of reggae with a female-only album. That’s laudable, but this stuff only works where the content is good. What’s extraordinary here is the delicate balance of diversity and consistency. It’s all elegantly produced, emphasising the vocals, but the vocals veer from Mandarin Chinese to Japanese to Hindi. A really impeccable effort.

I couldn’t agree more.

Listen on Spotify üé∂

One of the things I really appreciate about roon is the discovery tab that surfaces music in your library that you haven‚Äôt listened to for a while. This is today’s:

üé∂

My Album of the Week is And In The Darkness, Hearts Aglow from Weyes Blood.

Read more on inews.co.uk. üé∂
Prog Magazine‚Äôs Halloween playlist will kickstart your trick and treating…üéÉ
Listening to Between the Music: Volume One which is a collection of the tracks played between the acts at the End of the Road Festival, chosen by Simon Taffe. üé∂
Listening to FM, the new offering from Ryan Adams. I’ve been a fan since I first heard Heartbreaker, released in 2000, and I think he’s on top form with the new album. üé∂
Listening to the new Muse album, Will of the People. It’s a mix of rock, prog, glam and metal - play it loud! üé∂
Listening to a work-in-progress recording of a new song from the 2022 live line-up of Big Big Train, featuring Alberto Bravin on lead vocals. Watch on YouTube Sounds good so far. üé∂

Listening to Raise The Roof, the new album from Robert Plant and Alison Krauss. the long-awaited follow-up from Raising Sand. üé∂

Listen on Spotify.

Just listened to the brilliant new album from Elbow called Flying Dream 1.üé∂

Buy a copy from Elbow’s store or listen on Apple Music.
Listening to The Future from Nathaniel Rateliff & The Night Sweats. üé∂

Listening to Kites, the new release from melodic neo-prog band This Winter Machine. üé∂

Catch it on Bandcamp
Listening to Live to Tape: Volume 1 by Bahamas that includes tracks with The Secret Sisters and The 400 Unit üé∂

Listening to Decennium, the 10-year retrospective from English Folk/Prog/Rock group Gandalf’s Fist.

Listen or buy from Bandcamp üé∂
My Album of the Week is How Beautiful Life Can Be from The Lathums. üé∂

Listening to Vessel by The Accidentals on Apple Music üé∂

Try to give it time, life will teach you how to live

You just have to live it for a while
Trying out Apple Music, listening to star-crossed from Kasey Musgraves. Somehow I managed to get a free 6-month trial, so I’ll probably cancel my Tidal subscription üé∂
Listening to Reprise by Moby whilst writing a proposal. üé∂
Listening to From Dreams to Dust by The Felice Brothers on Tidal. I first discovered this band when I was looking for music to play on my Monday Music Mix show on ITfM Radio back in the day. üé∂

item.title: Two Fingers by Sea Power
item.description: This is the first track released from the new album, Everything was Forever, due February 2022. üé∂

Listening to A Beautiful Life by Heartless Bastards on Tidal. This band had passed me by, but pleased that they’re now on my radar. This album will be high on my “Best of 2021” list in December. üé∂

Listen here

item.title: Goodbye Spotify, Hello Tidal
item.description: After the 14 day Tidal trial, it was time to decide to stay with Spotify or move to Tidal. I prefer the new music suggestions that Spotify presents, but much prefer the UI of Tidal. I‚Äôve also got fed up waiting for Spotify to deliver the promised HiFi streaming functionality, which is important to me as I have a Naim streamer that is capable of making good use of the hi-res delivered by Tidal. You guessed it, I‚Äôve moved to Tidal. üé∂
<!-- raw HTML omitted -->

item.title: Spotify or Tidal?
item.description:
I‚Äôve flipped between both over the years, but currently using Spotify as I got a free six-month subscription when I bought a Sonos sound bar before Christmas. That‚Äôs about to expire, and it‚Äôs time to stump up ¬£9.99 a month.

The question is, should I go back to Tidal or stick where I am?

I listen to music on my MacBook, iPad, my phone and a couple of Sonos speakers located throughout the house. We also have a Naim streamer in the lounge, which means that I can make the best use of a high-quality source as provided by Tidal‚Äôs HiFi tier.

Spotify uses its Connect technology to send music to the Naim, whereas Tidal integrates with the Naim app, making for a more involved experience.

The only way to solve the puzzle is to have a sound off, play the same track on Spotify and Tidal and check whether I can hear a difference between the two to justify paying ¬£20 a month for Tidal.

I‚Äôve signed up for a 30-day Tidal trial. Let the games begin!

üéµ

item.title: Monday Music Mix: Best of 2020
item.description:
It’s been a tough year for us all, but many artists released some great new music during 2020. I’ve listened to dozens of new albums, and this playlist includes some of what I thought was the best tracks.

My Album of the Year had to be Letter to You from Bruce Springsteen.

I hope you enjoy some of the tracks I’ve chosen. Leave a comment with your suggestions.

¬†See you in 2021!

item.title: Monday Music Mix: 2020 Discoveries
item.description:
Here’s a list of music and artists that I discovered for the first time in 2020.¬†The list will grow throughout the year, so please come back to see what’s new.

Leave a comment with your suggestions.
